Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: A technical hurdle is preventing the mentee from advancing on the current project.
Situation2: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Story:
I gripped the steering wheel, my eyes darting between the snow-slicked road and the anxious passenger in my rearview mirror. The winter storm had turned the city into a maze of crawling cars and flashing hazard lights. My passenger kept checking his watch, his voice tight as he reminded me his flight was international—he couldn’t afford to miss it. I wanted to reassure him, to push the cab a little faster, but the roads were treacherous. Every turn felt like a gamble.

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from my mentor, asking for an update on the project. I’d hit a technical wall days ago, but I hadn’t told her yet. She expected me to communicate challenges right away, to be proactive and honest. But how could I explain my delay when I was stuck behind the wheel, responsible for someone else’s urgent timeline? The pressure from both sides pressed in on me—my mentor’s trust, my passenger’s hope. I felt torn, knowing I couldn’t meet both expectations at once.
